First thing, % pen is a counter to HIGH armour.

Flat pen is a counter to LOW armour.

Penetration is a COUNTER TO ARMOUR. Not the other way around.

If you're still puzzling about why flat pen is also a counter to armour, think this: If you have so much fire it can spread faster than the speed the firefighters can douse them. But it does NOT mean firefighters are countered by fire, isn't it?

......
......

Let's move on,

Lethality is not just flat pen. It's a GROWING flat pen. There is a difference.

If let's say there this narrow corridor that you have to pass a lot of times. And each time you try to, there is a defence system set in a way anything below 50 cm above ground would be filled with bullet.

Thus the logical counter is that: jump higher makes you dodge the shot easier.

That is the old flat pen.

......

Now, with the lethality, the defence system is set in a way more guns would be added to the mix with each passing, gradually pushing up the danger zones. This mean that you have to jump high and higher, not to overtake the defence system entirely like you could with the previous set up, but just so that you wouldn't be ridden with holes as the danger height went from <50 cm above ground, to <60, to <70 and so on.

You are FORCED to jump higher, and even when you do the threat is still equal; you still just barely avoid the shot even when you've already jumped a lot higher.

That's the lethality.

......
......

And I haven't touched on the fact since it's still a flat pen, it means it still kills the non-armour stacking unit harder thanks to its passive growth.

......

So in the grand scheme of things, lethality behaves like a % pen to armour stacking units, and behaves as an ever-growing flat pen to kill non-armour-stacking harder as time goes on.

It's effectively, the best of both flat and % pen. 

Lethality as a concept is simply, a mistake.

......

And it's also worse because Riot made flat pen now calculated AFTER % pen.

The current penetration in the game is just a flat out mistake that needs to be fixed.

your analogy falls flat because it's not really accurately portraying lethality vs flat armor pen.
Let's use your corridor with guns to stay consistent. With the old flat pen system, you had guns that shot anything below 50cm. So if you could jump 50cm, you would never get shot.
With lethality, you have guns that start off shooting anything below 10 cm, then 20, then eventually after you've gone through the corridor 18 times, they reach 50cm. 

If you can jump 50cm from the get go, the 10,20,30cm guns are completely useless and you have excess height. It's not until the 18th pass through that you barely clear them and need to be able to jump higher.

In the old system though, you had a maximum of 50cm worth of guns, whereas now by the 18th pass, you have something like 75cm available.

Theres kinda a twofold problem with building defensive. The first problem is average game time. This means on average you have enough time to around 3 full items(not counting boots) at best on average. If you build defensively the enemy ends up snowballing off the rest of your team who are not building defensively. So in a lot of situations its more effective to play defensively, look for picks, and try to carry teamfights.

Second problem is that defensive items are simply not very effective anymore. Back in old seasons defensive items did tend to outscale offensive items till someone could get a heavy pen item(like vod staff for example) but now they can shred through youe defenses without it and if you ever get behind, defensive items feel like even more of a joke.

What is amazing also is that you see proplayer do that, accordingly building defensive items when needed and also try to adjust the need of their powerspike along with it.

But just for the funny part, Lux rise as a support was when she was a TRUE support with using aftershock to have a lot of survivability with her Q and her shield being so strong lux player would start with it at lvl 1 and trade like raging hound. They would build full support item because her shield was so OP that you didn't need damage at all.

What amaze me is how delisuoned people are about the strength of building resistance.
We just had a big talk on the garen main subreddit about his ult being true damage but loosing base damage/ratio.
And I did the math and proved that even with the ratio and base damage nerf, it being true damage instead of magic damage made up for it (except in the villain case) because even a tiny amount of MR reduced the damage so highly (also Garen doesn't build MR penetration).

Anyway. Resistance aren't dumb, health isn't dumb, but at the same time it is sometime important that you get your powerspike to be able to do properly your job before paying for defensive item.

But it is the board here, nobody will listen to you, they rather rage at things, say yasuo killed their dog and that lux actually kidnapped xerath.

In all seriousness though I think part of the issue is the way damage & defensive compounds mathematically.
for ADC: Attack Speed x Damage x Crit Chance x Crit Multiplier x Armor Pen all compound.
for Tankyness: Health x Armor/MR compound

So giving up 1 item for an ADC you lose a HUGE amount of DPS for only a tiny amount of tankyness.  This tends to push damage dealers to full damage.

The math in this game is just in the wrong direction.  Damage and defense items should have diminishing returns... not increasing returns as they currently do.

The other thing that is backwards is how damage vs. health changes as you level.  For the sake of argument lets say
At Lv1 i takes like 10 seconds to kill a target
At Lv18 it takes like 2 seconds to kill a target

At Lv1 you are mostly fighting 1v1 or 2v2 in which case you can expect to live 10 seconds (or 5 seconds if 2 people are attacking you).
At Lv18 you are mostly fighting 5v5's in which case you can expect to live like 0.4s as 5 people pile on you during CC

It seems to me if you want fights to last the same ~5 seconds at Lv18 then health should scale more than damage so that as the game transitions from 1v1/2v2's to 5v5's the fights last the same amount of time.  But the opposite is true and damage scales more than health...  combined with the fact that 5 people are jumping on you makes you often die within CC.  The game's math is backwards IMO.
